headline: Chevron Strikes Deal With Israel To Build Natural Gas Supply Pipeline To Egypt
summary: Chevron Corp. has signed a deal with Israel Natural Gas Lines, Israel’s state-owned pipeline operator, to begin construction of the Nitzana natural gas pipeline that will transport natural gas from the giant Leviathan Gas Field to Egypt

headline: Chevron Advances with Hess Acquisition and Divestiture Plans While Maintaining Dividend Appeal
summary: Chevron Corporation (NYSE:CVX) is one of the 13 Best Fortune 500 Dividend Stocks to Invest In. Despite the decline in Q2 2025, the company progresses with acquisitions and divestitures. On August 1, 2025, Chevron Corporation (NYSE:CVX) reported Q2 2025 earnings of $2.5 billion, a huge drop from the prior year’s Q2 revenue of $4.4 billion. […]

headline: Global Oil Majors Return to Frontier Exploration for Growth
summary: Global oil and gas majors are increasingly refocusing on frontier regions and technically challenging areas to discover new conventional oil and gas volumes, driven by shrinking reserves and rising demand.

headline: Exclusive-Chevron exports of Venezuelan oil halved under new US authorization, sources say
summary: HOUSTON (Reuters) -U.S. oil major Chevron is only able to export about half the crude its joint ventures produce in Venezuela with the latest rules laid out by Washington, three sources close to the matter said.  The Treasury Department in late July issued a restricted authorization allowing Chevron to operate in the sanctioned country and export oil to the U.S., but it banned payments in any currency to the government of President Nicolas Maduro.  To comply with the permit, the joint ventures where the Houston-based company participates have been paying royalties and taxes with oil in kind, effectively reducing what Chevron can export to about 50% of the 240,000 barrels per day of crude the projects produce, the sources said.

raw.headline: Exclusive-Chevron exports of Venezuelan oil halved under new US authorization, sources say
raw.summary: HOUSTON (Reuters) -U.S. oil major Chevron is only able to export about half the crude its joint ventures produce in Venezuela with the latest rules laid out by Washington, three sources close to the matter said.  The Treasury Department in late July issued a restricted authorization allowing Chevron to operate in the sanctioned country and export oil to the U.S., but it banned payments in any currency to the government of President Nicolas Maduro.  To comply with the permit, the joint ventures where the Houston-based company participates have been paying royalties and taxes with oil in kind, effectively reducing what Chevron can export to about 50% of the 240,000 barrels per day of crude the projects produce, the sources said.
